semantic_title: Diabetes Mellitus Coding in Pregnancy, Childbirth and Puerperium
section_path: Section I > C. Chapter-Specific Coding Guidelines > 15. Pregnancy, Childbirth, and the Puerperium > g. Diabetes mellitus in pregnancy

content.full_text: Diabetes mellitus is a significant complicating factor in pregnancy. Pregnant patients who are diabetic should be assigned a code from category O24, Diabetes mellitus in pregnancy, childbirth, and the puerperium, first, followed by the appropriate diabetes code(s) (E08-E13) from Chapter 4. (Evidence: pg no: 67, L22-L27)
content.summary: Guidelines for coding diabetes mellitus in pregnant patients requiring dual coding from obstetric and endocrine chapters (Evidence: pg no: 67, L22-L27)
key_concepts: Diabetes as significant pregnancy complication (Evidence: pg no: 67, L23)
Dual coding requirement for pregnancy diabetes (Evidence: pg no: 67, L23-L27)
Sequencing priority for obstetric codes (Evidence: pg no: 67, L26-L27)

detailed_rules.rule_text: Code from category O24 should be assigned first, followed by appropriate diabetes codes E08-E13 (Evidence: pg no: 67, L26-L27)
detailed_rules.explanation: When a pregnant patient has diabetes, the obstetric complication code takes precedence in sequencing, followed by the specific diabetes type code (Evidence: pg no: 67, L23-L27)

workflow_steps: Step 1: Identify diabetes in pregnant patient
Step 2: Assign appropriate O24 code first
Step 3: Add secondary diabetes code from E08-E13

code_ranges.description: Diabetes mellitus in pregnancy, childbirth, and the puerperium (Evidence: pg no: 67, L23-L24)
usage_rules: Use as primary code for diabetes in pregnancy (Evidence: pg no: 67, L26)

code_ranges.description: Diabetes mellitus codes from Chapter 4 (Evidence: pg no: 67, L27)
usage_rules: Follow O24 codes to specify diabetes type (Evidence: pg no: 67, L27)

code_categories_mentioned: Category O24 - Diabetes mellitus in pregnancy, childbirth, and the puerperium

references_to.title: Long term use of insulin and oral hypoglycemics
references_to.explanation: Referenced for additional coding guidance on insulin use

coding_scenarios.scenario: Pregnant patient with pre-existing Type 2 diabetes
coding_scenarios.documentation_example: 32-year-old female at 28 weeks gestation with Type 2 diabetes mellitus
step_by_step: Step 2: Assign O24 code for diabetes in pregnancy
Step 3: Add E11 code for Type 2 diabetes

correct_coding.sequencing: O24 code first, then diabetes type code
correct_coding.rationale: Obstetric complication takes precedence with diabetes type specified (Evidence: pg no: 67, L23-L27)

incorrect_coding.common_mistake: Using only diabetes code without pregnancy complication code

warnings: Diabetes is a significant complicating factor in pregnancy (Evidence: pg no: 67, L23)
best_practices: Always sequence O24 codes before diabetes type codes (Evidence: pg no: 67, L26-L27)
common_mistakes: Using only diabetes codes without obstetric complication codes
tips: Remember dual coding requirement for pregnancy diabetes
implementation_notes: Applies to all types of pre-existing diabetes in pregnancy
clinical_context: Diabetes significantly impacts pregnancy management and outcomes
